intro: Acacia myrtifolia, commonly known as the myrtle-leaved wattle, is a flowering plant native to Australia. It is characterized by its slender, upright shrub form and its distinctive leaves, which are narrow and resemble those of myrtle. The plant produces yellow flowers in late winter to early spring, which are clustered in spherical heads. Acacia myrtifolia is adapted to dry, sandy soils and is often found in coastal and inland regions. It is a valuable plant for ecological restoration due to its ability to fix nitrogen and provide habitat for native wildlife.

This plant is commonly found in a variety of habitats, including dry sclerophyll forests and rocky outcrops. It is well adapted to the dry and often nutrient-poor soils of these regions. Acacia myrtifolia typically grows in open woodland and shrubland environments. Its distribution reflects its ability to thrive in the diverse climatic conditions across these Australian states.
